Nightmare for Carlsen: - One of the shocks of the time
Most things went wrong for Magnus Carlsen (28) on the second day of the World Cup final. Now the experts are hoping for "furious" Carlsen.
01 Nov 2019, 20:27 by Sondre Moen Myhre

Magnus Carlsen - Wesley So (1.5â€“10.5).


HÃ˜VIK ODDEN:

- Loss is really a crisis.
NRK expert and Aftenposten's chess columnist Atle GrÃ¸nn says it all at the Henie Onstad Art Center thinking. In the World Cup final Magnus Carlsen was a big favorite to win, almost everything has gone wrong.
However, this is not the biggest problem, says Green.
- The main problem is that So plays a little better. That's what's scary, he says.
After the party So was naturally very happy, but he did not want to say that the World Cup final had already won before the last day.
"I'm not thinking about it yet, but of course it will be amazing if I win," said So.


ALSO READ: Carlsen in trouble after new bang: - An earthquake in the world of chess


Hope for "furious" Carlsen
The World Cup gold goes to the first player to reach 12.5 points. That means So only needs two points from Saturday's potentially eight games.
First, four fast chess games should be played. Victory there gives two points. Then four lightning chess games are played. Victory there gives one point. If there is a draw, the points are split between the players.
So, So only needs to win one of Saturday's four fast chess games to be crowned the first official world champion in fishing chess.
- But it's not quite over, says Green, adding:
- If Magnus is furious now and So gets nervous, he can run over him.


- How much better is Carlsen than So in lightning and speed chess normally?


- Normally Magnus can score 70 per cent in lightning and speed chess against So, says Green.
In order for Carlsen to be able to save the World Cup gold at home, he must win at least three of the fast chess games and play a draw, and then win all of the lightning chess games.


Magnus Carlsen got tough against Wesley So on the second day of the World Cup finals.ğŸ“· Fredrik Hagen / NTB scanpix

- Will be the biggest shock in 84 years
The American made an acquisition early in Friday's final game. It didn't take many moves until So was an "officer" in front of the Norwegian.
Again, as he did during Friday's first game, chess expert Torstein Bae was full of praise for Carlsen's opponent.


- Has Carlsen been played here? asked the NRK broadcaster during the channel's chess broadcast.


"Yes, we almost have to say it," Bae concluded.
The chess expert believes a 1935 World Cup match between then-world champion Alexander Aljekin and weaker-ranked Max Euwe is the most shocking result of all time. Then the Dutch won Euwe.
Bae ranks a possible World Cup victory for So on the same level.
- That's at the level we're talking about here. There is no World Cup match I remember where number 12 in the world, in this case Wesley So, manages to catch up with a champion. I think even Euwe was significantly higher than that. So this is a sensation simply, the expert said.

Lost first game after mistake
In Thursday's loss, the two World Cup finalists played what was described as perfect chess until move 35. Then came the crucial loss from Carlsen.
In Friday's party, however, it was already trouble from the start. But little by little, Carlsen struggled into the party.
This time it held to the 37th move. Then Carlsen played his horse for the D4 and the chess computers made a big impact.
- This looks like a big mistake by Magnus Carlsen, Bae noted.
For So, on the other hand, it was important to find the one trait that still provided a great advantage. He did.
Then both players ended up in time as they approached the 40th move which gives fifteen minutes extra time.
So did not find the most accurate features, while Carlsen in turn made another move that gave So further advantage.
Eventually, Carlsen gave up the party, thus falling below six points.
